RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
5 YEAR UPDATES RE-SUBMITTAL


Regulatory Overview:

The EPA Risk Management Program, 40 CFR Part 68 was promulgated on June 20, 1996. Regulated Facilities are required to implement RMP and resubmit 5-year update of Risk Management Plans by June 21, 2004 as per Rule published in Federal Register on April 9, 2004. WTP #3 is a regulated facility, which has regulated chemical (Chlorine) above the listed threshold level of 2,500 lbs. The prepared RMP for re-submittal includes the following sections:

1. Registration 2. Offsite Consequence Analysis-Worst Case 3. Offsite Consequence Analysis-Alternate Case 
6. Five year accident History 7.Prevention Program for level -3 program 9.Emerghency Response

The following sections are not applicable to this site:

Sections 4.Flammables-worst case, 5. Flammables-alternate case & 8.Prevention Program for level 2 are not applicable to this site. This facility is also subject to OSHA 1910.119 ¿Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals"

Overall Safety Program:

This facility implements safety and health policies and procedures that are communicated in the Water Utilities Department Safety and Health Manual. These procedures are designed to protect workers from potential hazards when handling chemicals, operating a process and maintaining the equipment. The water Utilities Department has also prepared a Safety and Health Policy Statement. A few extractions are as follows:

¿It is the policy of Palm Beach County Water Utilities Department to ensure that every employee is entitled to a safe and healthful place to work and that activities are conducted in such manner as to minimize risk to employees and the surrounding community¿

¿Operational decisions affecting safety and health will receive greater consideration than those affecting productivity¿

¿Management commitment and support is given to all initiatives regarding safety and health¿.

Chlorine system is enclosed in a block cons

tructed building with metal doors. Included in the chlorine system is a gas scrubber that absorbs and neutralizes any chlorine gas emitted inside the chlorine building. The scrubbing system disallows chlorine gas to escape to the outdoor atmosphere.

Water Treatment Plant #3 has been also incompliance with OSHA 1910.119 ¿Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemical" for the Chlorine system since October 1995.

Risk Management Program rule allows the facility to incorporate the requirements of OSHA Standard and in effect, provide a facility plan that manages a formal prevention program and emergency response program. The Facility meets compliance with both Risk Management Plan Rule and OSHA's PSMP.


Process Description Overview:

This facility is designed to safely treat and provide 30 million gallons of safe drinking water to its customers each day meeting the requirements of SDWA with enough pressure for regular usage and fire demand. Chlorine gas is delivered in 1 Ton steel containers ( 2,000 Lbs of Chlorine).A bridge crane and hoist are used  to off-load the containers from the truck and place them inside the chlorine building in holders called trunnions. This prevents containers from moving. Empty containers are removed from the trunnions and placed on the truck to be returned to the supplier. 

Chlorine gas process is operated such that only four containers are in use at any time and another four containers are on-line in reserve. The containers being used and reserve containers are placed on scales. The scales are used to measure chlorine container contents and system usage. 

A vacuum regulator is connected to each 1 ton container and in turn is connected to piping that leads to the chlorinators. The chlorinators are connected to piping then to injectors. The Chlorination process begins when process water flowing through the injector induces vacuum that is maintained throughout the entire chlorine feed system. The chlorinator is set to allow a spec

ific amount of chlorine gas to travel to the injector. The vacuum allows the vacuum regulators on the chlorine containers to open and allow the chlorine gas to enter the piping system. In any situation that decreases the vacuum in the pipelines, the vacuum regulators on the containers will close. This safety feature prevents Chlorine from escaping any part of the system.

There are chlorine gas detectors inside the chlorine building. The detectors are set to alarm at 1ppm (parts per million) and 3 ppm and activate an audible and visual alarm. At 3 ppm the chlorine gas scrubber unit that is interlocked with the detector will activate. The scrubber system will maintain a negative pressure inside the chlorine building and draw the chlorine gas to where it will be neutralized. No chlorine gas is expected to be emitted to the outside of the chlorine building. 

The chlorine gas feed system has many built-in safety features that minimizes a chlorine gas release to the atmosphere. They are:
Vacuum feed system instead of a pressurized system
Vacuum regulator closes when vacuum is lost (broken pipe)
Vacuum regulator at each container
Chlorine detector and alarm system
Enclosed chlorine gas system-building
Chlorine gas scrubber system
Operational procedures
Emergency action Plans

Chlorine is used as a disinfectant in the water treatment process to eliminate the risk of exposure to waterborne diseases such as cholera, typhoid, and dysentery. Chlorine is an approved chemical by EPA and has been used as a disinfectant for almost a hundred years, and today Chlorine is safely used in 98% of all water systems.

Accidental Release Prevention Program:

Both EPA RMP and OSHA PSMP requires accidental release prevention program. The release prevention program in the Risk Management Plan for WTP #3 complies with the requirements of both agencies. 

The goal of release prevention program is reduce risk to the employees and the community of injury or death and protection of the environmen

t. The prevention program requires in-depth review of the chlorine process and allows for the implementation of key elements or programs that prevent a release. The following is an overview of the release prevention elements at WTP #2

Process Hazard Analysis :( PHA)

A PHA is a method of identifying, evaluating and controlling any risks associated with the chlorine process. Hazard and Operability study was used to review the entire chlorine process. Essentially it is a method where all parts of the system (from delivery of chlorine containers to endpoint of chlorine injected into the processed water) are looked at. Any equipment or existing operational procedure that reveals a potential of a release is scrutinized and recommendations are made that will lessen or eliminate the risk of a release. These recommendations are instituted where appropriate.

It should be noted that the Hazard and Operability Study is a multidisciplinary team approach that allows participants to review risk utilizing their  expertise. Some team members include a Process Hazard Analysis Team Leader, Plant Engineer, Plant superintendent, and Project engineer, Facility Chief Operator, Industrial Electrician, and Utility Plant Mechanic.

Operating Procedures:

Written operating procedures are in place for all the stages of chlorine system. The facility uses Job Safety Analysis format. This format describes steps to be taken in a job task in proper sequence and integrates critical safety precautions and personal protective equipment necessary to safely perform the task. As example, there are operating procedures for unloading new chlorine containers, system emergency shutdown, initial startup, chlorine scrubber test, chlorine detector test etc. Operators are trained and tested in these procedures.

Training:

The purpose of the training is to ensure that personnel working on or near the chlorine process are adequately trained and understands the inherent hazards and appropriate responses. The tr

aining is an integral part of preventing and mitigating the effects of accidental releases. The training section of the facility release prevention program specifies who and when an employee is to be trained and what the employee is to be trained on. The training is ongoing and any procedural change that is made is communicated to the employees.

Mechanical Integrity:

Mechanical integrity is defined as the process of ensuring that process equipment is fabricated from approved materials of construction and is properly installed, maintained and replaced to prevent failures and accidental releases. The facility Mechanical Integrity program addresses the following:
¿	Identification of critical process equipment and instrumentation
¿	Written maintenance, testing, and inspection schedule and procedures
¿	Maintenance, testing and inspection completion and documentation
¿	Correction of equipment deficiencies
¿	Quality insurance and assurance
¿	Maintenance personnel training

As part of the prevention maintenance program, equipment mechanical integrity is managed through computer generated work order system. This work order system handles all maintenance aspects of the chlorine system which includes work order management, planning and scheduling, asset, management and tracking, and reports and analysis. Identification of critical equipment is part of the work order system and is scheduled for preventive maintenance in accordance with manufacturer¿s recommendations.


Management of Change:

Regarding the chlorine system, change is defined as all modifications to raw materials, process technology, facility, equipment and procedures. Changes not considered as replacement" replacement in-kind¿ are subject to the facility management of Change Procedures and will not be performed without authorized approvals. Changes that have an effect on the chlorine process may be subject to a Hazard and Operability Study to analyze the change in equipment and conditions that may present risk.

Where changes are significant enough to require a change in process safety information, The management of Change Procedure must be performed in conjunction with the facility pre-startup Safety Review Procedure.

Pre-startup Safety Review:

A Pre-startup Safety Review is required when changes to the existing chlorine process results in a modification that is significant enough to require a change in process safety information. The purpose of the pre-satrtup Safety review is to ensure that facility is ready to safely operate the modified chlorine system. The review consists of a chlorine system checklist, approvals by the Plant Engineer, required documentation, operator and maintenance mechanic training, and corrections of any deficiencies discovered in the review.

Compliance Audits:

A Risk Management Program Audit is performed at least once every three years, in accordance with the Risk Management Plan requirements. An internal audit team performs the audit. The audit will include a review of facility's risk Management Program for the chlorine process. This includes required supporting documentation, interviews of personnel and a walk through and inspectrion of the chlorine process area.An audit report documenting all findings is prepared. This will include a listing of all deficiencies and recommended corrective actions. Plant management will ensure that all actions are resolved in timely manner Chlorine process operators and maintenance mechanics will be informed of all changes.

Incident Investigation:

All chlorine incidents at the facility, which result in or could have resulted in a release of chlorine, will be promptly investigated. The incident investigation procedure is part of the preventive maintenance program. The purpose of the incident investigation procedure is to identify the underlying causes of an incident and to implement corrective measures to prevent the incident from reoccurring. Chlorine release incidents are communicated immediately to appr

opriate government agencies.

The facility uses an investigative team approach to discover the contributory and root causes of an incident. The Director of Operations and Maintenance establishes the investigation team. Members of the team include the director of O&M, Plant Superintendent, Regulatory Compliance Program coordinator, Plant engineer, and affected and/or responding employees. Other individuals with appropriate knowledge will be asked to participate (i.e. plant electrician, plant mechanic, equipment supplier).

The team will prepare a report of the findings and submit recommendations that will prevent a similar incident from occurring. All recommendations are resolved. The incident investigation report findings and recommendations are communicated to all facility employees.

Employee Participation:

The facility recognizes that it is essential to involve its employee¿s in the development and implementation of this EPA Risk Management and OSHA Process Safety Management Programs. This facility has an Employee Participation Plan procedure as part of its prevention program. It sets forth procedures for involving employees in Process Hazard Analysis and other Risk Management Program elements. It also provides procedures for communicating employees right to access Risk Management Program Information, and documenting employee participation.

Hot Work Permit:

The facility has a Hot Work Permit procedure in its prevention program. The purpose of the procedure is to ensure that a hot work permit is issued for all hot work operations performed on or near the chlorine process. Hot work is defined as work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark producing operations. Chlorine is not flammable, but is considered an oxidizer and can support combustion of burning materials. There are  no materials in the chlorine building that can burn.

Emergency Responses:

This treatment facility is limited in its ability to provide a full respon

se to an accidental release of chlorine. Therefore, it is prudent to institute emergency action plans that allow a release to be managed by experienced responders such as Palm Beach County Fire/Rescue Responders and Public Safety Officials. The facility meets compliance with emergency action plans listed in OSHA1910.38.

The emergency action plans are performed on a first responder level which includes the recognition of a chlorine release, appropriate means of reporting a release, site emergency evacuation procedures and acoounting of evacuated personnel.

The emergency action plan is reviewed by Fire/Rescue Personnel. Facility and Fire /Rescue personnel will perform an annual drill at the facility. All facility employees receive training on the emergency action plan. Changes to the plan are communicated to all affected personnel.


Five year accident History:
Accidental releases of covered processes may result in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site or off -site, environmental damage etc. We are pleased to report that this facility did not have any accident involving accidental chlorine release during the last 5 years.
